author: By Megan O'Grady
title: Lily King Tries Her Hand at Something New: Short Stories
description: In “Five Tuesdays in Winter,” the longtime novelist strings together a series of small worlds that form their own solar system.
content: FIVE TUESDAYS IN WINTERBy Lily King
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder
title: The Ever-Evolving Art of Bonsai
description: The centuries-old craft is thriving as both a hobby and an art form, with contemporary practitioners around the world asking what lessons it can impart today.
content: IN 1913, A shipment of plants from the Yokohama Nursery Co. in Japan arrived in the port of San Francisco, among them a seven-foot-tall trident maple destined for the Japanese Pavilion at the Panama-Pacific International Exposition to be held two years later. More than a century old, the tree was an exemplar of the Imperial style, a type of bonsai developed for shoguns and feudal lords and named after the Imperial court during the 19th-century Meiji Restoration, an era of cultural transformation that arose following the country’s 214-year-long period of isolation. Evenly spaced branches reached out from a trunk twisted into gentle contrapposto, its clusters of spring green foliage suggesting the outline of an isosceles triangle. Like most bonsai from that time, the maple expressed an ageless ideal of the natural world wrested into equilibrium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: At 83, ‘Nimblewill Nomad’ Enters the Appalachian Trail Record Book
description: M.J. Eberhart, known by his trail name, hiked into Dalton, Mass., on Sunday and became the oldest known person to hike the more than 2,000 miles of trail from Georgia to Maine.
content: M.J. Eberhart, an 83-year-old retired eye doctor, had a strenuous weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: ‘Dickinson’ Uses the Civil War to Explore Modern Divisions
description: The creator Alena Smith had planned to set the final season during the conflict. “What we did not know was that there would be a pandemic, and that it would have echoes of the Civil War,” she said.
content: “Dickinson,” the trippy, playful and deeply passionate Apple TV+ series about the poet Emily Dickinson (Hailee Steinfeld), has always been about far more than Dickinson herself. Women and creativity, sexuality, fame, privilege, race, art as a bulwark against despair — the show touches on all of those.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: France Will Require Booster Shot for Those 65 and Older
description: President Emmanuel Macron, in a televised speech, said that older people will now have to get the shots to remain eligible for a vaccine passport.
content: PARIS — Seeking to regain control over his agenda five months before elections, President Emmanuel Macron of France on Tuesday announced the tightening of a key anti-coronavirus measure as infections keep rising across France and the rest of Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Looks at Puerto Rico’s Status in Case on Benefits
description: A federal law excludes residents of Puerto Rico from a Social Security program that provides monthly payments to needy people.
content: WASHINGTON — The immediate question for the Supreme Court justices at an argument on Tuesday was whether Congress was free to exclude residents of Puerto Rico from a Social Security program that provides monthly cash payments to older, blind and disabled people who cannot support themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: NASA Moves Moon Landing Deadline Back to 2025
description: The space agency acknowledged that it cannot return astronauts to the lunar surface by 2024, a timeline set under President Trump.
content: NASA is pushing back its deadline for returning American astronauts to the moon’s surface by as much as one year, officials announced on Tuesday. It’s the first official acknowledgment that 2024, the target set when Donald J. Trump was the president, cannot be met.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: exhilarating
description: This word has appeared in 192 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: India’s Covid turnaround has blind spots.
content: India’s coronavirus crisis, which was killing thousands of people a day just seven months ago, has eased after the nation’s leaders revamped policies and drastically ramped up their vaccination drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, says paid family leave ‘is not just about the mom.’
description: “It sets us up for economic growth and success, but it also just allows people to have that very sacred time as a family.”
content: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, has been hitting the phones, calling members of Congress to garner support for paid family leave in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: What Do I Owe My Difficult Mother-in-Law?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on why offering regular help creates sometimes unwelcome obligations of its own — and more.
content: My husband’s father passed away not long ago, leaving behind a wife. They were together for decades, but she was never beloved by the three stepchildren, and she never had children of her own. A person she considers a “nephew” lives in the same city we do and encouraged her to move to be near him. She couldn’t stay in her home alone as she was showing mild signs of dementia, and there was evidence, such as unpaid bills, that she was not managing her affairs well. We assisted her in moving across the country, and she is residing in a very nice senior community. We manage her finances and health care and visit a few times a month. The “nephew” does visit her, but nothing more, and has asked for financial support a few times since she moved. She is not an easy person in some regards; for example, she broods about perceived slights and then wants to change her will to cut out the person she feels slighted her (this is a chronic issue). My question is, what are our ongoing obligations, if any, to this person? Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Why New York Is Closing 6 Prisons
description: The number of people incarcerated in New York is less than half of what it was in 1999, and the facilities being closed are well below capacity.
content: New York officials on Monday announced plans to close six state prisons early next year, one of the largest such closings by the state as its prisoner population continues to decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sushma Subramanian
title: How Psychologists Can Help Treat Chronic Pain
description: As doctors and patients worry about the effects of painkillers, therapists are finding they can be a powerful salve for suffering.
content: Over the past two decades, as the opioid crisis has shaken the public’s view of painkillers and pharmaceutical companies have come under fire for their marketing practices, many patients are looking for alternatives. One of the leading contenders has become treating pain with talk therapy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malcolm Jones
title: A New Novel by Louise Erdrich Haunted by Covid and George Floyd’s Death
description: Set in Minneapolis mostly during 2020, “The Sentence,” by the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, is a ghost story about America’s current traumas that also evokes those of our collective past.
content: THE SENTENCEBy Louise Erdrich
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Workhorse Group records a big loss on electric vans.
description: The company, which lost its bid for a big Postal Service contract, has told investors it is under federal investigation.
content: Workhorse Group, a small producer of electric vans that has come under investigation by federal authorities, on Tuesday reported a loss of $81 million for the three months ending in September as a result of rising operating costs and a production stoppage related to a recall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Soumya Karlamangla
title: Where’s Gov. Gavin Newsom?
description: He’s in the office, according to increasingly frustrated staff members. But his critics on Twitter aren’t buying it.
content: Two weeks ago, Gov. Gavin Newsom announced he would be leading a delegation to the U.N. climate change summit in Scotland. Four days later, his office abruptly announced he had changed his mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Boosters, 1619 Project, Thanksgiving: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: 15-Minute Grocery Delivery Has Come to N.Y.C. Not Everyone Is Happy.
description: A half-dozen grocery services offer speed and convenience, but critics worry about their effect on neighborhood stores and crowded city streets.
content: The explosion of internet commerce has transformed New York City, with same-day delivery of a couch, a television or the latest laptop just a few clicks away as more companies compete for faster delivery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cameron Walker
title: Burning, Crushing, Stabbing: How Words Affect Pain
description: The language you use could make a difference on the pain you feel.
content: The pain showed up a few years ago — first slowly, then all at once. My right hip burned, my back ached. I went from running with my kids to not being able to walk down the block. I saw doctors, I did tests, I ranked the pain on a scale of one to 10, which felt like pulling a number — mine was seven — out of a hat. No illness or injury appeared, only the physical erosion from multiple pregnancies and age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Ball
title: The Climate Fight Isn’t About Morality. It’s About Cold, Hard Cash.
description: Plans for new power generation won’t meet global climate goals.
content: Nowhere is cutting carbon emissions more crucial than in the world’s emerging and developing economies, where the thirst for energy, and the output of carbon dioxide, is rising the fastest. New power plants there will lock in the trajectory of global warming for decades to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kari Cobham
title: Treating Chronic Pain Takes a Team. I Had to Build My Own.
description: The U.S. health care system can be difficult for anyone to navigate — even more so if you’re a Black woman. So one writer spent a decade building her own care.
content: If you’d seen me stroll into the hydration clinic one recent Tuesday afternoon, I looked young and fit with a curly mohawk and dangling earrings poking out the sides of a floral print mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Graham-McLay
title: New Zealand’s Sea Lions Are Back, and Crashing Golf Courses and Soccer Matches
description: After their populations were decimated by hunters, New Zealand’s sea lions are returning to the coasts — sometimes surprising locals by turning up in unexpected places.
content: They have surprised the users of public toilets by their sudden appearances and stopped a children’s soccer match by ambling onto the field. They have frolicked in a community swimming pool and shut down an urban road for weeks. One even gave birth near the 13th hole of a golf course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: What Do You Dream About Now?
description: Has the pandemic changed the kinds of dreams you have?
content: Do you remember your dreams most nights? Have you noticed a change in the kinds of dreams you have had during the pandemic?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Your Walls Don’t Have to Be Boring
description: Faced with a blank wall, most of us think paint or wallpaper. But there are more interesting possibilities to consider.
content: Facing a blank wall can be daunting. Often, we instinctively fall back on the most familiar option: “What color should I paint it?” Or maybe: “Should I add wallpaper?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Prejean
title: ‘Look at My Face,’ I Told a Man Before He Was Executed
description: The death penalty is wrong, but we can still uphold the dignity of the condemned.
content: The one time I was allowed inside a death chamber was as the State of Virginia took Joseph O’Dell’s life in 1997. That night, I stood close to the gurney, looking into Joe’s face, with my hand firmly on his shoulder as I prayed. In my prayer I asked God to affirm Joe’s worth as a beloved son possessing a sacred dignity that even the ones killing him could not take from him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Democrats Desperately Need Schools to Get Back to Normal
description: Strict Covid measures are creating fertile ground for the privatization movement.
content: Last Wednesday morning, Christopher Rufo, the architect of the right-wing crusade against critical race theory, sent me a message asking if I wanted to talk, I suppose because I was one of the first people to write about his project back in February. He was feeling triumphant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: ‘It went to my head’: Adam Neumann has regrets about his time at WeWork.
description: He also tried to revise the record about what happened.
content: Since being forced out of WeWork two years ago, Adam Neumann has stayed quiet in public about the near-collapse of the co-working empire he co-founded. But at the DealBook Online Summit on Tuesday, he admitted to regrets — and tried to revise the record about what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Tiffany Hsu
title: Meta plans to remove thousands of sensitive ad-targeting categories.
description: Ad buyers will no longer be able to use topics such as health, race or sexual orientation to target people with unwanted ads on Facebook or other Meta apps.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Meta, the social media company formerly known as Facebook, said on Tuesday that it planned to eliminate advertisers’ ability to target people with promotions based on their interactions with content related to health, race and ethnicity, political affiliation, religion, sexual orientation and thousands of other topics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A Trash Can From Myrtle Beach Washed Up in Ireland
description: “It reminded me straight away of maybe like a message in a bottle type scenario,” said Keith McGreal, who discovered the bin on Sunday afternoon while strolling on a beach with his family.
content: Keith McGreal was walking along Mulranny Beach in County Mayo, Ireland, on Sunday when he spotted a blue plastic barrel that had washed ashore like a message in a bottle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Mark Mazzetti
title: At the Willard and the White House, the Jan. 6 Panel Widens Its Net
description: What went on at a five-star hotel near the White House the day before the riot could be a window into how a Trump-directed plot to upend the election ended in violence at the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — “We are essentially in a national emergency,” Michael T. Flynn declared on Jan. 5, during an interview with the internet conspiracy theorist Alex Jones recorded in a luxurious suite at the Willard Intercontinental Hotel near the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: The Fed warns that China’s property market stress poses a risk to the U.S.
description: The U.S. central bank voiced concern as China Evergrande’s debt troubles have raised alarm in global financial markets and at home.
content: Turmoil in China’s real estate sector could threaten the United States, the Federal Reserve said in a report on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By André Wheeler
title: Mary J. Blige and a Perfume Take Over Rockefeller Center
description: Chanel No. 5 celebrates its 100th birthday with a big party.
content: Last Friday night, logomania swept Rockefeller Center as the luxury fashion house Chanel celebrated the centennial of its ever-popular fragrance No. 5 (also known as Marilyn Monroe’s favorite thing to wear to bed).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $2.05 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Los Angeles businesses confront a new vaccination mandate.
description: Thousands of gyms, restaurants, movie theaters, shopping malls, salons and other businesses are now required to ask customers for proof of vaccination.
content: Thousands of gyms, restaurants, movie theaters, shopping malls, salons and other indoor businesses in Los Angeles were required this week to start asking customers for proof that they had been fully vaccinated against Covid-19, under one of the nation’s strictest vaccination rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Dutch government rejects hundreds of millions of pieces of protective gear.
description: Roughly 308 million pieces of personal protective equipment bought by the Dutch government, including masks, goggles and gloves, were rejected for use in hospitals, a spokesman for the Dutch health ministry said.
content: Roughly 308 million pieces of personal protective equipment bought by the Dutch government, including masks, goggles and gloves, were rejected for use in hospitals, a spokesman for the Dutch health ministry said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Soundtrack of our Moment
description: Ahead of a  virtual event with Tom Morello, nominate a song that defines our charged times.
content: Every successful social movement had a great song to go with it. “We Shall Overcome” defined the civil rights era. Jimi Hendrix’s rendition of “The Star Spangled Banner” redefined patriotism during the Vietnam War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julianne McShane
title: Bittersweet Memories of Grand Prospect Hall
description: For couples married at the more than century-old venue in Brooklyn, which is now approved for demolition, their memories will soon be all they have left.
content: The Grand Prospect Hall in Park Slope, Brooklyn, has hosted countless weddings since 1903, when it was rebuilt following a fire in 1900 that destroyed the original structure erected in 1892. But for some of the couples who celebrated marriages at the Victorian-style banquet hall, which grew its reputation with long-running TV ads, their memories are now bittersweet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Joy Dong
title: As China’s Property Crisis Spreads, Beijing Says There’s Nothing to See
description: Global markets just weeks ago were fretting over the possible failure of Evergrande. Now the developer says the worst is over, even as other companies show signs of trouble.
content: When times were flush for the property developer China Fortune Land, it bought a trophy soccer club and recruited star athletes from Argentina. These days, the players with the club, Hebei F.C., are on indefinite leave because it can’t afford to keep the lights on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaime Lowe
title: How to Do a Voice-Over
description: Don’t be afraid to improvise. Avoid saying one line at a time.
content: “It’s not like you’re rolling film — when you’re recording voice, you can fail all you want,” says Eugene Mirman, a comedian and voice actor who plays Gene Belcher, the 11-year-old middle child on the animated television series “Bob’s Burgers,” which debuted in 2011. “That allows for more risk and taking chances and trying different jokes.” Be prepared to say a line dozens of times in a dozen different ways. “You could say lines in an angry, happy, questioning or fun way,” Mirman says. While voicing the character of Gene, Mirman emphasizes a youthful exuberance and optimism and cadence that’s slightly more upbeat than his everyday adult voice.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘His Skin Against Mine’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: So, I’m visiting my friend Donnie in Charlotte, N.C. He tells me that he has a younger sister who lives in Manhattan. I say I’d like to meet her. Soon after, Donnie’s father dies. I bring lemon chicken to the wake. Donnie calls me over to meet his sister, Bonnie. (Donnie’s twin brother is Ronnie.) Mesmerized, I shake Bonnie’s hand for a stupidly long time and keep repeating, “I brought chicken.” Some time later, Donnie calls Bonnie and says, “Remember the guy with the chicken?” Wary, she replies, “Yeah.” We married nine months later. — Bruce Julian
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino
title: Afghan Pilots Who Escaped Taliban Are Flown Out of Tajikistan
description: More than 140 Afghan Air Force pilots and crew members were evacuated to the United Arab Emirates three months after flying into Tajikistan to escape the Taliban.
content: More than 140 Afghan Air Force pilots and crew members detained in Tajikistan since mid-August after fleeing Afghanistan were flown out of the country Tuesday with the help of the American authorities, according to a retired U.S. Air Force officer who leads a volunteer group that has assisted the Afghans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman and Bryan Tarnowski
title: Athletes in a Ravaged Louisiana Town Try to Run Back to Normalcy
description: Hurricane Ida knocked down much of Grand Isle, La., but the town’s cross-country team is determined to compete in the state championship meet.
content: GRAND ISLE, La. — On an afternoon in late October, Londyn Resweber, 14, ran into the twilight of disaster. Little was intact two months after Hurricane Ida pummeled Louisiana’s only inhabited barrier island with sustained winds of 150 miles per hour and a storm surge measured as high as 11 feet. Almost everything that holds a town together had been blown apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: In Hong Kong, a mandatory smartphone app draws pushback and mockery.
description: Hong Kong’s latest “zero Covid” policy — a mandatory smartphone tracking app — is prompting online mockery and pushback.
content: Hong Kong’s latest “zero Covid” policy — a mandatory smartphone tracking app — is prompting online mockery and pushback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: Hospital Fire in India Leaves at Least 4 Infants Dead
description: The blaze, in a hospital in central India on Monday night, was the latest in a series of deadly fires at health care centers in recent months.
content: A fire engulfed the infant care unit of a hospital in central India on Monday night, killing at least four newborn children and injuring others, the latest in a series of deadly blazes at health care centers across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Sisson
title: How Data Is Reshaping Real Estate
description: Tech start-ups are offering new tools to help retailers and entertainment venues be more efficient by counting crowds, tracking foot traffic and following local shopping habits.
content: Jordan Fisher was troubled. Every variety of the Red Bull energy drink comes in a similar metallic can, and his company’s camera system, which tracks products that customers pick up in stores, was having trouble distinguishing them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Weighs Condemned Man’s Wish for Pastor’s Touch
description: A Texas death row inmate, John H. Ramirez, asked the justices to let spiritual advisers pray with and lay hands on prisoners as they await execution.
content: WASHINGTON — A Texas inmate’s request that his pastor be able to touch him and pray aloud with him in the death chamber met a mixed reception on Tuesday at the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Stroud
title: Scholars Cringe at the Term ‘Dark Ages.’ Dan Jones Explains Why.
description: Jones’s book “Powers and Thrones” is a comprehensive history of the Middle Ages that links the medieval era’s genuine achievements to modern times.
content: POWERS AND THRONES A New History of the Middle Ages
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Taíno People Want to Stop Christie’s Sale of Artifacts
description: The auction house says none of the objects to be sold in Paris on Wednesday are from illicit sources. But to those with roots in the Indigenous Caribbean culture, no price can be put on its history.
content: On the sidewalk outside of Christie’s auction house in Manhattan, Ra Ruiz León, who is Taíno, played the mayohuacán wooden slit drum. She had arrived at Christie’s with a sign reading “Respect Indigenous people! Return our artifacts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wall
title: How I Found Comfort in Volunteer Firefighting
description: Facing a world on fire turns out to be a great way not to contemplate one’s own misfortunes.
content: My daughter, Floriane, died in April 2015 at the age of 9. We had no idea she was anything other than perfectly healthy; in reality, she had a heart defect whose first outward symptom was sudden cardiac arrest. One evening we were playing together, and she collapsed. I tried to resuscitate her but did not succeed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Max Cleland, Vietnam Veteran and Former Senator, Dies at 79
description: He lost both legs and an arm in the war. Republicans impugned his patriotism by linking him to Osama bin Laden in an infamous TV spot.
content: Max Cleland, who lost both legs and an arm during the Vietnam War and later became a senator from Georgia, only to lose his seat after Republicans impugned his patriotism, died on Tuesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Singapore will stop covering Covid costs for those who decline to be vaccinated.
description: The change, which takes effect on Dec. 8, comes as the number of severe cases has stabilized but remains high, the Health Ministry said.
content: Singapore will no longer cover the medical costs of Covid-19 patients who are eligible to get vaccinated against the virus but choose not to, the country’s Health Ministry said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Emily Anthes
title: Scientists confront a new source of vaccine misinformation: Aaron Rodgers.
description: When news broke that Aaron Rodgers, the Green Bay Packers quarterback, had tested positive for the coronavirus last week and was unvaccinated, Mr. Rodgers justified his decision to not get inoculated by speaking out against the highly effective vaccines and spewing a stream of misinformation and junk science.
content: When news broke that Aaron Rodgers, the Green Bay Packers quarterback, had tested positive for the coronavirus last week and was unvaccinated, Mr. Rodgers justified his decision to not get inoculated by speaking out against the highly effective vaccines and spewing a stream of misinformation and junk science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Ethiopia Seizes 16 U.N. Workers Amid Efforts to Halt Tigray War
description: The detentions aggravated the already tense relations between the United Nations and the Ethiopian government over war and famine in the country’s northern Tigray region.
content: Sixteen United Nations staff members in Ethiopia’s capital have been seized by the country’s authorities in recent days, the chief U.N. spokesman said Tuesday, injecting new tension into the organization’s troubled relations with the government as it faces a year-old civil war and famine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Protest outside New Zealand’s Parliament assails sweeping new Covid mandates.
description: About 3,000 people marched through Wellington, New Zealand’s capital, on Tuesday to protest vaccination requirements and coronavirus restrictions, forcing a lockdown of Parliament and closure of local streets.
content: About 3,000 people marched through Wellington, New Zealand’s capital, on Tuesday to protest vaccination requirements and coronavirus restrictions, forcing a lockdown of Parliament and closure of local streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Twitter expands its subscription service to news articles.
description: The company is pushing to find new sources of revenue.
content: Twitter said on Tuesday that it would give users access to ad-free articles from The Washington Post, Reuters, BuzzFeed and other publications through its subscription service, called Twitter Blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Vaccine refusal in Romania.
content: Vaccine hesitancy in Romania, stoked by powerful forces online and in the real world, has left the country with Europe’s second-lowest vaccination rate and the world’s highest per capita death rate from Covid-19 in recent weeks. Around 44 percent of adults have had at least one dose, ahead of only Bulgaria, which is at 29 percent. The E.U. overall stands at 81 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Dobbs
title: The Quiet Scientific Revolution That May Solve Chronic Pain
description: New science is rewriting the book on chronic pain — and may make treatment more accessible
content: Chronic pain is both one of the world’s most costly medical problems, affecting one in every five people, and one of the most mysterious. In the past two decades, however, discoveries about the crucial role played by glia — a set of nervous system cells once thought to be mere supports for neurons — have rewritten chronic pain science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: ‘We Had Their Baby, and They Had Our Baby’: Couple Sues Over Embryo ‘Mix-Up’
description: Daphna and Alexander Cardinale, the plaintiffs in a lawsuit against a Los Angeles-area fertility clinic, say they endured a painful custody exchange after DNA testing.
content: Something didn’t seem quite right to Daphna Cardinale after she gave birth to her second child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Reaches Cease-Fire With Resurgent Taliban Militants
description: The Pakistani government said it would offer amnesty for insurgents who are willing to disarm.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A cease-fire between Pakistan and the Pakistani Taliban went into effect Tuesday, weeks after Prime Minister Imran Khan announced that his government was in talks with some militant groups that were willing to lay down arms in return for amnesty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Furman
title: In Oaxaca, a Meal to Celebrate a Pioneering Artist’s Legacy
description: To fete the opening of a new exhibition of work by — and inspired by — Ana Mendieta, the curator Su Wu gathered friends for a comal-cooked brunch prepared by chef Thalia Barrios Garcia.
content: On a brisk October morning, a crowd of 30 artists, designers and curators gathered in downtown Oaxaca, Mexico, to toast a new public art space. The curator and writer Su Wu, who has lived in Mexico City, some 280 miles northwest, since 2017, had brought the group together to celebrate, too, the boundary-breaking Cuban-born artist Ana Mendieta’s “Siluetas” series of photographs and films (1973-78), from which five works appear in the inaugural show at La Clínica, a onetime medical office that was recently reimagined by Ramón Jiménez Cuén, the former director of the Museo de Arte Contemporáneo de Oaxaca, as an unconventional exhibition venue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Padma Lakshmi’s Thanksgiving Turkey: Slow Roasted and Richly Sauced
description: The host of “Taste the Nation” and “Top Chef” isn’t a professional chef herself. That’s why her bird is stress-free and foolproof.
content: There are two doors, nearly identical, that open into the downtown Manhattan penthouse of Padma Lakshmi. One leads to her office and staff work spaces and the other to her yipping Chihuahua and the living areas. Ms. Lakshmi, the television host and producer, author and activist, moves between the two wings (and upstairs to the bedrooms) in fuzzy slippers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Thandiwe Newton Feeds Her Soul With Critical Race Theory and Cleo Sol
description: The “Westworld” actress talks about her new Audible recording of Tolstoy’s “War and Peace” and why too much entertainment can be bad for you.
content: For Thandiwe Newton, recording an audiobook isn’t merely sinking into a comfy chair in front of a mic and trying not to trip over the words. Especially when it’s a literary behemoth like Tolstoy’s “War and Peace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Dean Stockwell, Child Actor Turned ‘Quantum Leap’ Star, Dies at 85
description: He appeared alongside Frank Sinatra and Gene Kelly when he was not yet 10. He later had signature roles in movies like “Married to the Mob” and “Blue Velvet.”
content: Dean Stockwell, who began his seven-decade acting career as a child in the 1940s and later had key roles in films including “A Long Day’s Journey Into Night” in 1962 and “Blue Velvet” in 1986, while also making his mark in television, most notably as the cigar-smoking Al Calavicci on the hit science fiction series “Quantum Leap,” died on Sunday. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Are Scented Candles Harmful to Your Health?
description: When candles burn, they release various vapors and particles into the air, but research suggests that using them is safe.
content: You may have seen some scary headlines about the hidden dangers of scented candles — including those claiming that certain types (particularly candles made of paraffin wax) are “toxic” and can release harmful, cancer-causing chemicals into the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: New Initiative Aims to Change How Movies Portray Muslims
description: An advocacy group has created a worker database with help from Disney to bring more Muslims into the filmmaking process.
content: A new initiative to promote the inclusion of Muslims in filmmaking has been created by an advocacy group with the support of the Walt Disney Company — following a report issued this year that found that Muslims are rarely depicted in popular films and that many Muslim characters are linked to violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks Seeks to Delay Union Election as Vote Nears
description: The move, and a visit by the company’s former chief executive days before the scheduled start of balloting at three Buffalo-area stores, reflect the stakes.
content: Just days before workers at three Starbucks stores in the Buffalo area were scheduled to begin voting on unionization, both labor and management took steps that reflect the high stakes involved, including an attempt by Starbucks on Monday to delay the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Macron announces a new vaccine rule for people 65 or older in France.
description: Though the country has a high vaccination rate, new coronavirus cases and hospital admissions have been increasing in recent weeks.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France announced the tightening of an anti-coronavirus measure on Tuesday, as virus cases kept rising across France and the rest of Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Often Lent, but Never Returned
description: Jennifer Lee and Victor Galson wax poetic.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Welcome back to Jennifer Lee and Victor Galson, who are making their second appearance in the New York Times Crossword. Today’s puzzle is a celebration of humorous poetry, drawing on a famous poet’s clever observations about animals to create a fun and breezy Tuesday puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: If It’s Not Critical Race Theory, It’s Critical Race Theory-lite
description: The country’s education debate isn’t made up.
content: Former Gov. Terry McAuliffe lost last week’s Virginia race for governor in part because the victor, Republican newcomer Glenn Youngkin, pledged, “On Day 1, I will ban critical race theory in our schools.” This followed an October CBS News poll that found that 62 percent of likely Virginia voters considered “school curriculums on race and history” a “major factor” in how they’d vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juno DeMelo
title: I Have to Believe This Book Cured My Pain
description: A science writer investigates the 30-year-old claims of an iconoclastic doctor who said chronic pain was mostly mental.
content: Every time someone tells me their back’s been giving them trouble, I lower my voice before launching into my spiel: “I swear I’m not woo-woo, but … ”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: What Moves Swing Voters
description: A creative new poll tries to understand.
content: Political pundits often talk about swing voters as if they were upscale suburbanites, like “soccer moms” or “office-park dads.” And some are. But many are blue-collar. They are the successors to the so-called Reagan Democrats, who let Republicans win the White House in the 1980s and Democrats retake it in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Dazzling Accessories That Catch the Light
description: This season, stand out from the crowd with sparkly, crystal-encrusted bags and shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s happening today at the DealBook summit.
description: On the first day of the DealBook Online Summit, hosted by Andrew Ross Sorkin, top newsmakers in the worlds of business, policy and culture discuss the future of technology, gender equality, the direction of democracy and life after the pandemic, among many other consequential topics. Register here to attend, free of charge, and catch up on any sessions you may have missed.
content: On the first day of the DealBook Online Summit, hosted by Andrew Ross Sorkin, top newsmakers in the worlds of business, policy and culture discuss the future of technology, gender equality, the direction of democracy and life after the pandemic, among many other consequential topics. Register here to attend, free of charge, and catch up on any sessions you may have missed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
title: India Eased Its Covid-19 Disaster. Fears of Complacency Remain.
description: The success represents a major victory for Narendra Modi’s government, but a recent slowdown in new vaccinations has sparked worries.
content: NEW DELHI — India’s coronavirus crisis, which was killing thousands of people a day just seven months ago, has eased after the nation’s leaders revamped their policies and dramatically ramped up their vaccination drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: The U.S. urges Beijing to release a Chinese citizen journalist who highlighted Covid.
description: Zhang Zhan, who was imprisoned after exposing the failures of the government’s initial response to the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan, is near death, friends and family say.
content: The first known person to be prosecuted for documenting China’s coronavirus crisis is seriously ill in a Shanghai prison and could die if she does not receive treatment, her family and friends say — a disclosure that has drawn renewed attention to China’s efforts to whitewash its early handling of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Powell’s Books Survived Amazon. Can It Reinvent Itself After the Pandemic?
description: As much as any city, Portland, Ore., has been through hell. Its landmark store, Powell’s Books, must finally build a viable online business while recapturing its downtown success.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Over its half-century in the heart of Portland, Powell’s Books has survived an unending array of foundational threats — the oft-anticipated death of reading, the rise of Amazon, the supposedly irretrievable abandonment of the American downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Beacon for a Cancer Recovery
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 9, 2021.
content: “Everything I’ve done, every movement has been a conversation with death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Frontline health workers in England must be vaccinated by April.
content: All frontline health workers in England must be vaccinated against Covid-19 by next spring to keep their jobs, Britain’s health secretary said on Tuesday, a move that employers and trade unions warned could aggravate staff shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Tressie McMillan Cottom Interviews Kiese Laymon for ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
description: A conversation with the acclaimed writer.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode hosted by Tressie McMillan Cottom featuring Kiese Laymon. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Is a Red Wave Coming for Biden’s Presidency?
description: The Republican Party has a lot of news to celebrate after last week’s elections. Why are voters cooling toward the Democratic Party?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Top Questions for the DealBook Online Summit
description: What we would like to ask Apple’s Tim Cook, the WeWork founder Adam Neumann, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, and more.
content: Today is the first day of the DealBook Online Summit, with a packed lineup of newsmakers in the worlds of policy, business and culture. Andrew will interview them about the pressing issues of the day, from how tech giants balance innovation and privacy to the role business plays in creating opportunities for underrepresented groups and the next steps in the global vaccine campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Infrastructure Week Finally Happened
description: Getting past incompetence, cronyism and ideology.
content: Thirteen Republican members of the House voted for the infrastructure bill now headed for President Biden’s desk. That may not sound like much, but given the intensity of G.O.P. partisanship — the loser in the New Jersey governor’s race still hasn’t conceded — getting even that many Republicans to back an initiative that might help Mr. Biden is amazing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: The Fresh Prince of Belles-Lettres? Will Smith Has a Memoir.
description: From rap stardom to movie stardom, “Will” traces its hero’s quest out of West Philadelphia.
content: Fourth of July weekend, 1996. America has gasped en masse watching aliens detonate the White House in the movie “Independence Day” and, at 3 a.m. in Los Angeles, the telephone of its young star, Will Smith, jangles him awake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Ana Swanson
title: The Biggest Kink in America’s Supply Chain: Not Enough Truckers
description: Long hours and uncomfortable working conditions are leading to a shortage of truck drivers, which has compounded shipping delays in the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — Facing more than $50,000 in student debt, Michael Gary dropped out of college and took a truck driving job in 2012. It paid the bills, he said, and he could reduce his expenses if he lived mostly out of a truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Hearst’s magazine journalists protest a mandatory return to the office.
description: The company’s journalists joined the Writers Guild in 2020 and have asked in contract talks for a flexible work arrangement. The company has rejected that request.
content: More than 300 employees at Hearst’s magazine division have signed a petition objecting to the company’s plan to have them return to the office starting next week, and their union has filed a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brodie Lancaster
title: The Future Is Big. So Courtney Barnett Still Sings About Small Things.
description: This Australian musician’s third album, “Things Take Time, Take Time,” rolls in a breakup, therapy and the pandemic as well as death and other certainties.
content: MELBOURNE — Courtney Barnett has been spending a lot of time thinking about the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: If You Can Make It There, the Mets Would Love to Have Your Number
description: As the team’s search for a general manager continues, Sandy Alderson said the pressure of New York City has been a factor. “It’s a big stage and some people prefer to be elsewhere.”
content: CARLSBAD, Calif. — The Mets play in a vibrant city, in the largest market in Major League Baseball. They have passionate fans all over the region, country and world. Their stadium is only 12 years old. They have arguably the best pitcher in baseball in Jacob deGrom. And under their owner, Steven A. Cohen, the richest in baseball, the franchise has ample resources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: How to Exercise With Chronic Pain
description: Working out may seem like the last thing someone in pain wants to do. But it can bring relief.
content: For 25 years, Wei Liu had been practicing and teaching tai chi, including to people suffering from chronic knee pain, believing the exercises strengthen legs and instills calm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: U.S. Urges Court Not to Block Vaccine Mandate on Employers
description: The Biden Justice Department filed its case before an appeals court that has temporarily halted the measure.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday argued that the federal government had all the power it needed to require large employers to mandate vaccination of their workers against the Covid-19 virus — or to require those who refuse the shots to wear masks and submit to weekly testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: Three Y.A. Novels About the Challenges and Charms of Growing Up
description: “Aristotle and Dante Dive Into the Waters of the World” (by Benjamin Alire Sáenz), “Bad Girls Never Say Die” (by Jennifer Mathieu) and “Himawari House” (by Harmony Becker) all explore, through very different approaches, what it means to grow up.
content: ARISTOTLE AND DANTE DIVE INTO THE WATERS OF THE WORLDBy Benjamin Alire Sáenz
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Monika Pronczuk and Anatol Magdziarz
title: West Accuses Belarus of Orchestrating Migrant Crisis at Polish Border
description: Poland has massed troops at the border, the European Union’s eastern frontier, to keep migrants camped there from crossing into the country.
content: Poland has massed thousands of troops on its border with Belarus to keep out Middle Eastern migrants who have set up camp there, as Western officials accuse Belarus’s leader of intentionally trying to create a new migrant crisis in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: SpaceX Carries NASA Astronaut Mission Home With Safe Water Landing
description: The Crew-2 astronauts spent nearly 200 days in orbit, and their stay aboard the International Space Station was punctuated with surprises.
content: Four astronauts inside a capsule built by SpaceX streaked across the Florida night sky like a meteor before splashing down in the Gulf of Mexico Monday night. The water landing capped an eventful six-month stay on the International Space Station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr and Michael J. de la Merced
title: G.E. Breaks Up With Its Storied Past
description: The company, once the epitome of corporate ambition, plans to split itself into three separate companies.
content: It was the quintessential American company, a corporate behemoth whose ambition matched the country’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: The toilet on the Crew Dragon capsule was out of service. The crew had to use diapers.
description: The malfunctioning toilet was first detected in another SpaceX capsule last month.
content: Last week, the SpaceX Crew-2 capsule was all clear to make its trek back home, but one thing stood in the way: its toilet. While the vehicle had been cleared to return to Earth, the toilet remained offline for the duration of the trip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The Superheroes From House of Slay Are Here to Stay
description: How five fashion friends got a starring role fighting discrimination and hate in a new comic book series.
content: One evening, just before Halloween, a party was held at Chinese Tuxedo, a trendy Cantonese restaurant in Chinatown in Manhattan. Attendees entered through a back alley lit by yellow lanterns, past graffitied walls covered in posters of superheroes. Inside they sipped Champagne while Asian drag queens, West Dakota, Panthera Lush and Dynasty, writhed around the restaurant’s poles. The evening’s invitation had dictated: “Dress to Slay.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Goes After Ted Cruz for Going After Big Bird
description: Jimmy Kimmel said conservatives like Ted Cruz have some bizarre beliefs: “The elections are rigged, the deep state runs the world, and Big Bird is working for Merck now.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Jail Oversight Board That Failed to Sound the Alarm
description: The Board of Correction, which has the power to monitor Rikers Island and other city jails, took no action as deaths behind bars increased.
content: It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at a little-known city agency responsible for monitoring conditions at the city’s jails. It took no action as deaths increased earlier in the year. We’ll also look at the resurgence of wildlife in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Chamber Music Society’s Leaders on Balancing Old and New
description: Wu Han and David Finckel take a conservative course navigating passionate feelings about the future of classical music.
content: Inside the offices of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center hangs an old letter from an alarmed listener.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shola Lawal
title: The World Needs to Quit Oil and Gas. Africa Has an Idea: Rich Countries First.
description: As negotiators at the Glasgow climate talks try to agree on greenhouse gas cuts, African leaders say poorer countries can’t be expected to remake their systems as quickly as wealthy ones.
content: LAGOS, Nigeria — The staff at Big Cabal, a media start-up, wanted to ditch its diesel generator, but needed something to keep the office air-conditioners running. The generator was noisy, expensive and, maybe worst of all, bad for the environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: 4 New Y.A. Fantasy Novels Full of Dark, Enchanting Twists
description: These fantasy novels — “Year of the Reaper,” by Makiia Lucier; “Beasts of Prey,” by Ayana Gray; “Skin of the Sea,” by Natasha Bowen; and “Gilded,” by Marissa Meyer — will transport you to magical worlds.
content: YEAR OF THE REAPERBy Makiia Lucier
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Tim Cook has invested in cryptocurrency personally, but Apple has no plans to do so.
description: “I think it’s reasonable to own it as part of a diversified portfolio,” Apple’s chief executive said at the DealBook Online Summit.
content: While Apple might not offer users a way to pay with cryptocurrency anytime soon, its leader has invested in it personally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks workers at three more Buffalo-area stores file for union elections.
description: The petitions were submitted as employees at three other stores prepared to vote in a unionization effort.
content: One day before ballots were scheduled to go out to workers at three Buffalo-area Starbucks in a vote on unionization, workers at three other stores in the area filed petitions with federal regulators on Tuesday requesting elections as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Two Acclaimed Writers on the Art of Revising Your Life
description: Kiese Laymon and Tressie McMillan Cottom on vulnerability, revision and love.
content: Many of the most contentious debates right now center on whether we, as individuals — and as a country — are willing to revise. To revise our understanding of history. To revise the kind of language we use. To revise the nature of our personal, and national, identities. To revise how we act in our everyday relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Motorcycle Adventures
description: How do you feel about motorcycles? Do you have any connection to biker culture?
content: A recent New York Times Magazine story focused on a writer who bought their first motorcycle during the pandemic, only to become enamored with biker culture. Have you ever taken a ride on a motorcycle? What was it like? Why do you think biker culture — choppers, leather jackets, the open road — can be so appealing? Would you ever want to ride a motorcycle? Where would you go if you could take a motorcycle adventure?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: ‘Free Joe Biden’: Sean Maloney on How Democrats Can Get Back on Track
description: In an interview, the leader of the House Democrats’ campaign arm acknowledged the major challenges facing the party but defended its agenda and its continued focus on Donald Trump.
content: In the days since Democrats were battered in elections across the country last week, criticism of the party’s policies and electoral strategies has rained down, alongside dire forecasts of its prospects in the 2022 midterms. The flagellation has come not just from gleeful Republicans, but from many in the Democratic ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Making of a Feel-Bad Boom
description: What do people mean when they talk about “the economy”?
content: By the usual measures, the U.S. economy has been booming this year. Employment has risen by more than five million since January; a record number of Americans say this is a good time to find a quality job, a sentiment reflected in the willingness of an unprecedented number of workers to quit (yes, high quit rates are a good sign).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nekima Levy Armstrong
title: Black Voters Want Better Policing, Not Posturing by Progressives
description: We need effective, non-militarized policing with accountability for bad officers. Getting that takes hard work, not just rhetoric.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — This city always prided itself for being a progressive place where everyone could thrive. At least, that was true for white people. Black residents all too often faced persistent racism and inequality — in education, homeownership, income and employment — and in the way the police treated us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Sununu to Run Again for New Hampshire Governor, Rejecting Senate Bid
description: National Republicans had seen a potential campaign by Gov. Chris Sununu against Senator Maggie Hassan, a Democrat, as one of their best shots to upend the Senate’s 50-50 split.
content: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire, a Republican, surprised his party on Tuesday by announcing that he would not run for U.S. Senate next year, rejecting a full-court press from national Republicans who tried to recruit him to compete for a Democratic-held seat that the G.O.P. believed could determine control of the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: What ‘Structural Racism’ Really Means
description: As the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. wrote, “an edifice which produces beggars needs restructuring.”
content: Whether for inspiration, new ideas or simply as a refresher, it is important to revisit the classics of whatever constitutes your field of interest. It was with that in mind that I spent much of the weekend rereading the 1948 book “Caste, Class, and Race: A Study in Social Dynamics,” an influential (if now somewhat obscure) work of sociological analysis by the Trinidadian scholar Oliver Cromwell Cox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Nikola Jokic Suspended After Shoving Markieff Morris
description: Jokic, the Denver Nuggets star who is the reigning league M.V.P., was responding to a hard foul by Morris. Both players were ejected, and Morris was fined.
content: Nikola Jokic of the Denver Nuggets, the reigning N.B.A. most valuable player, was suspended without pay for one game on Tuesday after shoving Miami’s Markieff Morris to the floor during a game Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Harrison-Caldwell
title: Words Full of Sound and Fury
description: In the 19th century, the use of grandiloquent, fanciful words was all the rage, which proves that overcomplicating things has always been funny. And is it a uniquely American phenomenon? Some linguists believe so.
content: Have you ever been inveigled? Bamboozled? Have you been hornswoggled by lexiphanic rodomontade? Have you fallen victim to the flummery of an ultracrepidarian?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Do Democrats Have a Messaging Problem?
description: Some critics say the Democratic Party is struggling to respond to issues seized upon by conservative news media.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Officials Illegally Campaigned While in Office, Watchdog Finds
description: Mr. Trump’s son-in-law and his chief of staff are among those accused of violating a law designed to prevent federal employees from abusing their power.
content: WASHINGTON — Thirteen of President Donald J. Trump’s most senior aides — including his son-in-law and his chief of staff — campaigned illegally for Mr. Trump’s re-election in violation of a law designed to prevent federal employees from abusing the power of their offices on behalf of candidates, a government watchdog agency said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: ‘America Is Back’ Pelosi Says at Glasgow Climate Talks
description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez was among a group of Democratic lawmakers who traveled with Ms. Pelosi to barnstorm the COP26 climate summit.
content: GLASGOW — Speaker Nancy Pelosi and nearly two dozen House Democrats barnstormed global climate talks here on Tuesday, claiming that “America is back” in the effort to slow global warming, even as their party remains divided over a $1.85 trillion budget bill upon which their climate agenda depends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Rolls-Royce plans to build small nuclear power plants in Britain.
description: Backed by the government and other investors, the industrial giant proposes to build as many as 16 generating plants.
content: Rolls-Royce, the British jet engine maker, said on Tuesday that it was forming a business to build a series of smaller, cheaper nuclear reactors as Britain looks for ways to cut carbon emissions and to reduce the costs of nuclear energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: When Kilauea Erupted, a New Volcanic Playbook Was Written
description: Scientists learned lessons from the 2018 outburst on the island of Hawaii that are changing how responders prepare for eruptions in other places.
content: Back in the summer of 2018, Wendy Stovall stood and stared into the heart of an inferno.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Oklahoma Supreme Court Throws Out $465 Million Opioid Ruling Against J.&J.
description: The 5-1 decision is a setback for those who are fighting to hold big drug makers accountable for the opioid epidemic.
content: Oklahoma’s highest court on Tuesday threw out a 2019 ruling that required Johnson & Johnson to pay the state $465 million for its role in the opioid epidemic. It was the second time this month that a court has invalidated a key legal strategy used by plaintiffs in thousands of cases attempting to hold the pharmaceutical industry responsible for the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Metallurgist Admits She Falsified Test Results for Steel Used in Navy Submarines
description: For more than 30 years, Elaine Thomas altered test results for more than 240 steel productions while working for a foundry that provides metal for U.S. Navy submarines.
content: A former metallurgist at a foundry that provides steel used to make U.S. Navy submarines pleaded guilty in federal court in Tacoma, Wash., on Monday to falsifying test results that measured the strength and toughness of the metal — a practice that prosecutors said she continued for more than three decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: The ‘Rust’ Shooting Spurs a Debate Over Using Guns on Film Sets
description: Alec Baldwin, who fatally shot a cinematographer with a gun he had been told was safe, has called for productions to hire police officers to monitor gun safety.
content: Ever since the actor Alec Baldwin fatally shot the cinematographer of the film “Rust” last month with a gun he had been told, incorrectly, contained no live ammunition, the debate on the use of firearms on sets has been growing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The case against vaccine mandates.
content: President Biden’s vaccine mandate for large businesses is facing a challenge in court that could turn out to be a procedural blip, or the first step in the unraveling of the entire measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Austin Mitchell, Robert Jimison, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachel Quester, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett and Chris Wood
title: A Conversation With a Virginia Democrat
description: Representative Abigail Spanberger, a moderate, discusses her reservations about the Biden agenda and her party’s prospects.
content: In a bipartisan win for President Biden, Democrats and Republicans have passed a trillion-dollar infrastructure plan. Now comes the difficult part — trying to win approval for a $2 trillion social spending bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Yasmin Marikar
title: It’s Never Too Late to Become a Bollywood Actor
description: Richard Klein left behind his life as a Hebrew day school teacher in California and became an actor in Mumbai, often playing a “mean British officer.”
content: It’s Never Too Late” is a series that tells the stories of people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canada approves Pfizer-BioNTech boosters for all adults.
description: Some provinces have already started to offer booster shots to higher-risk populations. Tuesday’s announcement standardizes eligibility criteria nationwide.
content: Canada’s health agency authorized booster shots of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine nationwide on Tuesday, broadening eligibility to anyone over the age of 18, regardless of what vaccine they received initially.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Gotham, in the Former Gotham Bar & Grill Space, Nods to Its Predecessor
description: A new steak spot from Laurent Tourondel, Le Coucou’s long-awaited reopening, and more restaurant news.
content: The grandeur of Gotham Bar & Grill remains in this newly redecorated space, now ready for its debut with new owners, a new chef and a somewhat reduced name. The architect James Biber, who designed the original restaurant with its signature parachute light fixtures, was on the job again, this time introducing a somewhat more subdued palette with splashes of color from the art on the walls (all for sale). There is new lighting, by David Weeks, the owner of David Weeks Studio in Brooklyn, that soars across the room in a series of stretched pale fabric wings. There’s a bright little lounge area up front. Bret Csencsitz, Gotham Bar & Grill’s former manager, and his business partner, Kevin Conrad, an environmentalist, bought the restaurant after it closed during the pandemic, and took on the reboot. Sensitive to Gotham Bar & Grill’s long tradition — it first opened in 1984 — Mr. Csencsitz named Ron Paprocki, its pastry chef of 10 years, to be the executive chef. His menu, unquestionably American and seasonal, relies on ingredients like Elysian Fields lamb, heritage pork and heirloom carrots, with inventive accompaniments. “The sauces are the game-changers for me; they’re French at the heart,” Mr. Paprocki said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Satellite Hopes Meet Internet Reality
description: Satellite internet is exciting, but it needs to be part of a bigger effort to get more people online.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: They Say Colleges Are Censorious. So They Are Starting a New One.
description: The founders of the University of Austin say they want to defend intellectual dissent, and declare that something in higher education is fundamentally broken.
content: A group of scholars and activists are planning to establish a new university dedicated to free speech, alarmed, they said, “by the illiberalism and censoriousness prevalent in America’s most prestigious universities.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Police Make Arrest in a Series of Random Shootings in Missouri
description: The attacks occurred for several weeks across poor Black neighborhoods in the St. Louis area. Many were linked to a single gun. But whose?
content: It started outside St. Louis in mid-September, when a man waiting at a bus stop was shot and severely injured by a stranger. The next day, the body of a teenage girl shot in the back of the head was found in the same neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Silverstein
title: The 1619 Project and the Long Battle Over U.S. History
description: Fights over how we tell our national story go back more than a century — and have a great deal to teach us about our current divisions.
content: On Jan. 28, 2019, Nikole Hannah-Jones, who has been a staff writer at The New York Times Magazine since 2015, came to one of our weekly ideas meetings with a very big idea. My notes from the meeting simply say, “NIKOLE: special issue on the 400th anniversary of African slaves coming to U.S.,” a milestone that was approaching that August. This wasn’t the first time Nikole had brought up 1619. As an investigative journalist who often focuses on racial inequalities in education, Nikole has frequently turned to history to explain the present. Sometimes, reading a draft of one of her articles, I’d ask if she might include even more history, to which she would remark that if I gave her more space, she would be happy to take it all the way back to 1619. This was a running joke, but it was also a reflection of how Nikole had been cultivating the idea for what became the 1619 Project for many years. Following that January meeting, she led an editorial process that over the next six months developed the idea into a special issue of the magazine, a special section of the newspaper and a multiepisode podcast series. Next week we are publishing a book that expands on the magazine issue and represents the fullest expression of her idea to date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Rebecca Robbins
title: Moderna and U.S. at Odds Over Vaccine Patent Rights
description: Moderna’s patent application names several employees as the sole inventors of a crucial component of its coronavirus vaccine, excluding three government scientists.
content: WASHINGTON — Moderna and the National Institutes of Health are in a bitter dispute over who deserves credit for inventing the central component of the company’s powerful coronavirus vaccine, a conflict that has broad implications for the vaccine’s long-term distribution and billions of dollars in future profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Harris and Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Blue States, You’re the Problem
description: Why do states with Democratic majorities fail to live up to their values?
content: It’s easy to blame the other side. And for many Democrats, it’s obvious that Republicans are thwarting progress toward a more equal society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By YZ Chin
title: Women Seeking Intimacy Through Food, Mathematics and Rhythm
description: From a New York au pair to a kathak dancer in India to an aspiring mathematician in Oslo, the heroines of three debut novels seek solace in vocation.
content: WIN ME SOMETHING By Kyle Lucia Wu 263 pp. Tin House. Paper, $16.95.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the Mosh Pit and ‘Raging’ Came to Hip-Hop
description: The tragedy at Travis Scott’s Astroworld turned attention to how rap festival performances are increasingly oriented toward the rowdy.
content: In the last decade, hip-hop has become increasingly familiar with the mosh pit, stage diving and crowds that take on lives of their own. No one’s career embodies that more than Travis Scott, whose fans are known as Ragers and who has built an empire on encouraging them toward abandon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Reporting on a Chaotic and Unfamiliar Place That Used to Be Home
description: In “O Beautiful,” all that stands between a writer and the career of her dreams is a trip to the land of her nightmares.
content: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and short-story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tesla shares slide 12 percent as Musk’s stock-sale pledge continues to reverberate.
description: Since Friday, Tesla has shed about $200 billion in market valuation.
content: Shares of Tesla fell sharply for a second consecutive day, dropping 12 percent Tuesday, in a continuing shakeout after Elon Musk, the company’s founder, suggested on Twitter that he would sell 10 percent of his stake in Tesla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Dowling
title: My Journey Into the Dark With a Punk Rock Orchestra
description: From a bar in Queens to a cave in West Virginia, a Times editor went back to her roots as a music writer.
content: “Where are the bats?” I wondered to myself as I scanned the towering, weeping walls of Lost World Caverns, a subterranean natural landmark and tourist site in West Virginia. It was October 2019, and I was there to report on the punk rock orchestra Sloppy Jane, which had arranged to record its second full-length album, “Madison,” deep inside Lost World. I grew up in New York, and as a city kid, I thought all caves had bats. But the only things remotely chiropteran at Lost World were a few laminated articles about Bat Boy, a fictional tabloid character, posted by the cave’s entrance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Maps Reshape American Politics’
description: In this lesson, students will learn all about redistricting and gerrymandering. Just how fair is our current system?

title: Hundreds of Migrants Gather at Belarus-Poland Border
description: Hundreds of people, largely from the Middle East, camped at the Belarus-Poland border in frigid weather seeking to enter Poland. Western officials say Belarus is trying to orchestrate a refugee crisis at its borders with the European Union.

title: Corrections: Nov. 9, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 9, 2021.
content: An article on Sunday about Democratic losses in rural Virginia misstated the origin of The Homestead in Hot Springs, Va. It is believed to have been founded as a lodge in 1766, not in the late 1800s. (Its operation as a luxury resort dates to when it was rebuilt in the late 1800s.) Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the location of a monument to Confederate soldiers. It is in Warm Springs, not Hot Springs, Va.
source.name: The New York Times
